text: Interceptor/separator type, size, and capacity match mechanical schedules and local bylaw requirements
Manufacturer’s submittals stamped and reviewed; flow rate and retention volume confirmed
AHJ (e.g., city plumbing inspector) notified if pre-installation approval required
Concrete pad/support base level and sized to hold interceptor weight (if not slab-on-grade)
Pipe inlet/outlet slopes meet design (1–2%) and piping connected with flexible couplings or expansion joints
Cleanout installed on both sides of the tank for maintenance
Venting system connected to interceptor per manufacturer and local plumbing code
External sensors (if specified) for high-level or oil detection connected and tested
Signage or labelling provided above access covers or service ports
System filled with water and observed for leaks or settlement before backfilling or concealment
Functional test completed: verify no bypass of interceptor; float/oil skimmer devices tested
Maintenance access clearance verified per local municipal code or design drawings
Initial cleaning scheduled prior to occupancy or system turnover
Operation manual, maintenance logbook, and manufacturer warranty submitted
Owner trained on cleaning schedule, maintenance frequency, and disposal records
Commissioning and inspection forms signed off by AHJ

id: • National Plumbing Code (NPC Canada), CSA B481 Series (Grease Interceptors)
• Local Municipal Bylaws (e.g., City of Calgary Sewer Bylaw 14M2012)
• Manufacturer Specs: MIFAB, Schier, Zurn, Highland, Canplas, Rockford Separators
